name: Newfoundland
metaDescription: Newfoundlands face heart disease, hip dysplasia, and bloat. Compare the best pet insurance for Newfies—coverage for giant breed conditions & more.
intro: Newfoundlands are sweet, patient giants famous for their water rescue abilities and gentle nature. Their massive size brings serious health concerns including heart disease, hip dysplasia, and bloat. Insurance is essential for managing the high cost of giant breed care.
whyInsurance: Newfies face subaortic stenosis (heart defect), hip and elbow dysplasia, and bloat. Their size means everything costs more—anesthesia, medications, surgery. A single cardiac diagnosis can mean thousands in ongoing care.
mustHave: Cardiac coverage — Heart disease is very common in Newfies
Orthopedic coverage — Hip, elbow, and cruciate issues
Bloat coverage — Deep-chested breed at high risk
High or unlimited limits — Giant breed care is expensive

costIntro: Newfoundlands have higher insurance costs due to their size and health risks. Here's what to expect:

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for a Newfoundland?
faqs.answer: Yes, it's essential. Newfies are prone to heart disease (SAS), hip dysplasia, and bloat—all expensive conditions. Their giant size means higher costs for everything. Insurance protects you from major financial surprises.

faqs.question: What is subaortic stenosis (SAS)?
faqs.answer: SAS is a heart defect where tissue below the aortic valve obstructs blood flow. It's hereditary and common in Newfoundlands. Mild cases may need monitoring; severe cases require medication or surgery. Screening is recommended.

faqs.question: Why are Newfoundlands expensive to insure?
faqs.answer: Giant breeds cost more because treatment costs more—larger drug doses, bigger equipment, more anesthesia. Combined with their predisposition to expensive conditions, insurance companies price accordingly.

faqs.question: Should I screen my Newfoundland for heart disease?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Cardiac screening (echocardiogram) is recommended for all Newfoundlands, especially before breeding. Early detection allows for management before symptoms appear. Reputable breeders screen their dogs.

faqs.question: How long do Newfoundlands live?
faqs.answer: Typically 8-10 years. Their shorter lifespan makes quality of life during those years even more important. Insurance helps ensure you can afford the best care without financial constraints.

finalCta: Protect your gentle Newfie from unexpected health costs. Compare quotes and find the right coverage today.
